An earlier version of this essay was presented at the UCLA Center for Seventeenth‐ & Eighteenth‐Century Studies and the William Andrews Clark Memorial Library seminar, “Braudel Revisited. The Mediterranean World, 1600–1800” (October 26, 2002), in commemoration of the one‐hundredth anniversary of Braudel’s birth. Fellow panelists Peter Burke and Jacques Revel offered helpful comments. My thanks to Maurice Aymard for valuable offprints and bibliography, and to Michael Bernstein, Terry Burke, Luce Giard, Jules Kirshner, Danny Vickers, and especially Bill McNeill for their generous comments, corrections, and suggestions.

body.p: The reception of Fernand Braudel’sLa Méditerranée et le monde méditerranéen à l’époque de Philippe IIwould appear to be simple and straightforward in the English‐speaking world.1It has been very well documented, with so much written about the book and its author—by Braudel himself, Mme. Paule Braudel (his wife, research assistant, and collaborator from 1933), Braudel’s colleagues, students, followers, admirers, biographers, and journalists—that one may wonder if anything new could possibly be said.2Pierre Daix’s 1995 biography, for example, counts the great success ofLa Méditerranéein its diffusion: 2,500 copies of the 1949 edition printed, 50,000 of the 1966 second edition and an initial run of 20,000 of that edition in paperback, with translations of the first edition into Italian and Spanish (in Mexico) in 1953 and of the second edition into English in 1972–73, Spanish, Hungarian, and Polish in 1976, Portuguese in 1983, Italian in 1986, Serbo‐Croatian in 1987, Greek in 1991, German, Dutch, and Japanese in 1992, and Chinese in 1996.3In America, John Elliott welcomed the translation of volume 1 in 1973: “It will doubtless stand as one of the crowning achievements of twentieth‐century historical craftsmanship.”4In England, Helmut Koenigsberger’s 1974 review went further: “It is recognized as a masterpiece, a classic you can compare with the great classics of history writing, from Thucydides to Gibbon and from Macaulay to Burckhardt.”5In 1975, Richard Mowery Anderson revised J. H. Plumb’s initial mixed review in theNew York Times Book Review(1972) with rave acceptance of “the most significant historical work of our time” as “a revolution in historical thought, the only one commensurate with our century and its global necessities.”6Samuel Kinser declared in a 1981AHRgraced with a cover photo of Braudel, “If the Nobel Prize were given to historians, it would almost certainly have been awarded to Fernand Braudel.”7By 1992, Peter Burke confidently agreed that it was “a book with a good chance to be regarded as the most important historical work of the century.”8

When, then, should we date the conquest of America by Braudel’sMediterranean? Or, as Jacques Revel and Lynn Hunt put it, when did America discover theAnnales?9No one would dispute the date of the American reception of Braudel to be the five‐year period from the 1972 English translation of volume 1 and the famous December 1972Journal of Modern Historyissue on Braudel to the Inaugural Conference held on May 13–15, 1977, of Immanuel Wallerstein’s Fernand Braudel Center for the Study of Economics, Historical Systems, and Civilizations at the State University of New York at Binghamton.

In those five short years, “History with a French Accent,” as theJMHeditor William H. McNeill titled his introductory “fanfare on behalf of this majestic monument of twentieth‐century historiography,” exploded onto the English and American book market in excellent and inexpensive English translation.10TheJMH,as the official journal of the Modern European History Section of the American Historical Association, stamped the hot‐off‐the‐presses first volume of the Harper & Row English translation ofLa Méditerranée(and volume 2 soon to follow in 1973) with its imprimatur.11TwoAnnalesessay collections and a review article onAnnalistehistoriography also appeared in 1972,12four more translations in 1973,13two books, a review article and a panel at the AHA annual meeting in 1974,14and in 1975 the first of seven volumes of collected essays on selected topics from theAnnales. 15In 1976 Traian Stoianovich’s paean to theAnnales 16appeared, along with Braudel’s lectures at Johns Hopkins (published in 1977).17A translation of Le Roy Ladurie’s inaugural lecture to the Collège de France18and Braudel’s apotheosis at the inaugural conference of Wallerstein’s Center19ended the five‐year period in spring 1977.

The number of citations and publications of Braudel and theAnnalisteshas continued to grow exponentially from that mid‐1970s moment. An online search of JSTOR’s 242 English‐language journals for all citations mentioning “Braudel” for the years 1927 (when Braudel published his first two French book reviews) through 2000 yields 2,851 items that confirm my periodization.20Only two Braudel references are recorded in English citations in the 1930s and ten items in the 1940s. But he receives much more notice in the 1950s, with 130 citations—not unexpectedly, given the publication ofLa Méditerranéein 1949; and there is double that number in the 1960s, with 285 citations—a total of 525 citations before the December 1972JMHissue, which alone includes seven items by the JSTOR method of counting. In the five‐year period from December 1972 through June 1977, JSTOR records 274 citations, about one‐half the number of citations that had come in the previous forty‐five years. And for the twenty‐three years from July 1977 through December 2000, an additional 2,052 citations have appeared in English, for an average of almost ninety citations per year, more than three times the number of annual citations in the 1960s.

Having confidently answered the easy question of dating the reception, one discovers that three more difficult and interesting questions emerge. First, why was Braudel received so favorably in 1972 but not earlier, after the 1949 first edition ofLa Méditerranée?Second, what do and what should readers take away from the book? After reading 1,082 pages—not counting bibliography or indexes, just text and notes—in the 1966 French second edition, or 1,244 pages in the 1972–73 English translation, what do readers—students, specialists, and general readers—remember? And, third, why should we still remember either Braudel the man (1902–85), especially given theAnnalistehistoriographical tradition’s disdain for biography,21or his book, now, more than a third of a century after the revised second edition, more than a half century after its original 1949 publication, and almost two‐thirds of a century after its “main outline … was determined if not entirely written by 1939”?22

In a word, the problem I want to address is memory. That Braudel wrote the first draft from memory as a prisoner of war highlights the theme, but I am especially interested in the relationship between memory and the passage of time—that is, how memory is subject to forgetfulness, manipulation, erosion through honest mistakes that we might call “tricks” of memory, nostalgic distortion, emendation to even scores or inflate résumés, propagandistic monumentalization by keepers of the flame, the information explosion, and the Renaissance commonplace that fame yields to time.23Pierre Nora has brilliantly examined the problem of memory’s mediation of past and present as “les lieux de mémoire.” His specification of the relationship between memory and time locates memory in an untranslatable place, site, or realm and explores memory as “a response to the acceleration of history, to rapid social change, and to the problems of identity.”24

There is nothing canonical in my three‐question organization—why the reception happened when it did, what readers remember from the book, why remember the author and his book—but the answers should help us to understand better Braudel’s object of study and how he understood space and time in his holy trinities of plains, plateaus, mountains andlongue durée, conjoncture, événements. 25I have linked space and time in Braudel’s material world to their appearance between memory and history, because such “realms,” or, in Renaissance terms, “theaters” of memory bring us to the central problem of Braudel’s “possibilism”—that is, individual choice and freedom, what contemporaries considered to be the Renaissance predicament offortuna(determinism) versusvirtù(human action). This relationship between structure and event is the point of departure for both praise and blame of Braudel, for he “is either praised for his love of the concrete or condemned for his obsession with non‐incremental details.”26

sec.title: The U.S. Reception
sec.p: To return to 1972, then, neither the English publication ofLa Méditerranéenor the proclamations of theJMH’s editor and two distinguished English‐language authorities on either side of the Atlantic made Braudel’s book a classic. It already had arrived. When Hexter, in his 1972JMHarticle, mined early reviews ofLa Méditerranéeto examine “some of its flaws” and later quoted critical “fragments from appraisals,” he did so not because “the appraisals themselves were unfavorable. Quite to the contrary, most of them were sympathetic, some enthusiastic.” Rather, Hexter wanted to point out that, despite the reviewers’ “overall judgment,” they displayed “similar misgivings” about Braudel’s success in achieving his goal of integrating multilayers of time, especially the short‐term events in Part III.27But did early reviewers share more than “misgivings”?

The three most influential American journals in the field—The American Historical Review, The Journal of Economic History,andThe Journal of Modern History—all published favorable reviews in 1950.28Garrett Mattingly of Columbia set the tone in his JanuaryAHRreview. Despite criticisms and caveats about Part III, he concluded: “But this review should not close on a note of disparagement. Whatever its faults, this is a brilliant, exciting, and profoundly stimulating book, a creditable labor of scholarship and historical imagination. Every student of sixteenth century history ought to read it; every lover of the art of history should welcome it.” Melvin M. Knight of Berkeley, a French colonial historian,29reviewedLa Méditerranéein theJEHin a neutral fashion by thoroughly describing the book’s contents and emphasizing its revisionist theses and evidence in five pages, “The Geohistory of Fernand Braudel,” but he withheld judgment except for praising its coverage of Mediterranean history as “admirable.” Richard A. Newhall from Williams College, an expert on the Crusades and late medieval England and Normandy, wrote a one‐pageJMHreview that emphasized Braudel’s impressive efforts, details, and suggestiveness but found that the author posed more questions than he answered and opined that “probably Braudel would disclaim any intent to do more than provide information leading toward a possible synthesis by some future historian.” For his part, Braudel, no doubt, would have made no such disclaimer; he surely believed he had presented that very synthesis.

The most often cited example of American historians’ early resistance, naiveté, or misunderstanding with respect to Braudel’s work is Bernard Bailyn’s “Braudel’s Geohistory—a Reconsideration” in the Summer 1951Journal of Economic History,which, readers will recall, had just reviewedLa Méditerranéesix months before in its November issue.30Bailyn (b. 1922) was then a twenty‐nine‐year‐old graduate student at Harvard, a war veteran, and was writing in a confident, mature voice after a year of study in Paris. He was hardly naive; in fact, he was deeply influenced by theAnnales. 31Asked about his review, Bailyn emphasizes that “there was no twenty year gap before recognizing Braudel and theAnnales.”32Rather, theAnnaleswere fully assimilated, but Braudel was simply not writing good history.

Bailyn’s diction and derision in his 1951 review are devastating. He found Braudel’s tripartite temporal schematization “an exhausting treadmill … Braudel has mistaken a poetic response to the past for an historical problem … there was no central problem Braudel wished to examine.” He repeated his assessment that “what is painfully lacking from this huge, rambling book is the integration of its parts that could result from the posing of proper historical questions … [and that] Braudel could overcome the naturally resulting incoherence only by classifying, separating, compartmentalizing.” Bailyn chastises Braudel for not knowing “the most elementary teaching of the sociologists about social change … that no important element moves in isolation.” He argued that the book was “uncritically heralded” by “[Lucien] Febvre’s passionate encomium” in the 1950Revue historiquebecause of the felt need for new principles of synthesis due to the “avalanche of specialized monographs as well as the historical studies of the social scientists.” Bailyn concluded with a categorical rejection of “Braudel’s book [as] a revolution in historical method” and echoed the DecemberJMHjudgment of Newhall, who had been an important influence on Bailyn in college, that Braudel’s work was “rather a summary in three parts of a large body of knowledge.”33

What some may think was the rhetoric of a young Turk trying to make his mark, or simply a critique growing out of U.S. historiography’s long antitheoretical tradition, I believe can instead be explained in three complementary ways. First, Bailyn was not alone in finding fault with the lack of integration in Braudel’s tripartite structure. In a 1957JMHarticle, “French Scholarship in Modern European History: New Developments since 1945,” Edward R. Tannenbaum characterized the debate as one between conventional and innovative history: “[Braudel’sLa Méditerranée] has stimulated an international controversy between conventional historians and those who want history to include the techniques of other disciplines in an all‐embracing synthesis.”34Hans Kellner, writing inHistory and Theory(1979), summarized the early criticism ofLa Méditerranéeas posing the question, “Was the work an enormous heap of diverse materials or a truly revolutionary step in historical methodology?”35

Second, Bailyn, who went on to an extraordinary career in U.S. colonial history,36was expressing his own early views on ideas and methods in history, which belong to a long pragmatic tradition in American historiography that he still affirms today: “I was never interested in the application of theories or models of any kind to history, and have never referred to any such writings in anything I’ve written.”37Bailyn expressed views similar to those in his 1951 review of Braudel twenty‐five years later in aJEH(1977) book review of Stoianovich.38With a wider audience before the “bully pulpit” he occupied in his 1981 AHA Presidential Address, he again took aim at Braudel to make his point: “Braudel’sMéditerranéehas been justly celebrated for its wealth of information, much of it esoteric, and its revealing, at times brilliant, descriptions of the way people lived; but it should be known too for its ahistorical structure, which drains the life out of history.”39In 1994 Bailyn’s position on French historical scholarship remained much the same: “Braudel, of course, was a great historian, but the structure of his famous book on the Mediterranean is metahistorical; it’s directed not at history but at certain notions about the nature of history, which is quite different.… It’s a different way of thinking about history … as historians [the French] live in a somewhat different world.”40Bailyn remembers his original Braudel review and his further engagement with FrenchAnnalistehistory in a matter‐of‐fact way, as part of his constant vision of history: “There is nothing dramatic in any of this. I was studying French medieval history and reading the French historical journals, came on Braudel, and wrote what I thought. Subsequently I’ve followed up somewhat on the problems I saw in his kind of history. My current work on Atlantic history is explicitly the opposite of Braudel’s Mediterranean history.”41

Third, Bailyn represented a new approach to economic history, that of entrepreneurial history.42Economic history in America was itself a relatively new discipline that was greatly stimulated by the World Wars, the postwar recovery, and subsequent problems from the Great Depression to the Cold War.43Edwin F. Gay, himself an economic historian, who was founding dean of the Harvard Business School in 1907 and cofounder of the National Bureau of Economic Research in 1920, promoted the establishment of two institutions in 1940, the Economic History Association and the Committee for Research in Economic History (CREH), which spawned entrepreneurial history as a research agenda.44The Rockefeller Foundation provided funding to establish the offshoot Entrepreneurial History Research Center at Harvard in the academic year 1948–49.45The entrepreneurial ideology of the Center emphasized the creative individual as risk taker and prime mover in making choices for economic change and growth.46

The curious problem about Bailyn’s review is why theJEHpublished this second rather long review so soon after Melvin Knight’s very professional review the previous November. Since reviews are usually commissioned, not unsolicited, who or what was behind this piece?

We should look, I believe, to the silent partners in Bailyn’s review, theJEHcoeditors: the great Venetian economic historian Frederic C. Lane (1900–84)47at Johns Hopkins, and the distinguished U.S. economic historian Thomas C. Cochran (1902–99),48then at the University of Pennsylvania—both promoters of the entrepreneurial history philosophy. The editors of theJEHhad announced a new policy in the winter 1951 issue, the number immediately following the Knight review: The journal was being expanded from a biannual to a quarterly, and it would include a new section dedicated to “Review Articles and Discussion.” TheJEHwould not necessarily exclude a book “merely because it has once been reviewed here. Accordingly we are making this flexible arrangement for appraisal and reappraisal of important contributions to economic history.”49Perhaps the editors were not pleased with the Knight review and sought another scholar with good French and entrepreneurial history sympathies to intervene in the discussion on the reception of Braudel’s work. Bailyn, for his part, initially recalled that “I came on Febvre’s ecstatic review of Braudel [inRevue historique(April–June 1950)]. So I read the book, and was rather shocked at its non‐historical nature and the other things that I wrote in the short piece. I wrote the piece and sent it in. The issues I found in the book went to the main concerns I had about historical thought, and writing seemed to be worth the trouble.”50Possibly Bailyn may have also been aware of Braudel’s work through his mentor Newhall’s December 1950JMHreview, which might have prompted him to write an expanded review on his own per the newJEHpolicy. Regrettably, Bailyn does not remember the details of the submission of his revew.51Solicited or not, Bailyn’s review was published by theJEHeditors, as it expressed their entrepreneurial history agenda.

Although Lane knew Braudel’sMéditerranéewell enough in September 1950 to refer to its description of the inland sea’s economic realities as “brilliantly pictured,” as the Europeanist coeditor of theJEHhe planned the journal’s expansion with Cochran and would have been well aware of Bailyn’s pending June 1951 negative review before he left the coeditorship that year.52Lane and Braudel had not met in the Venetian archives when Braudel and Mme. Braudel worked there during their Brazilian winter vacations in 1935 and 1936; in fact, they only met for the first time in Paris, when Lane, as assistant director of the Division of Social Sciences of the Rockefeller Foundation, was based there for two years—from June 1951 (the very time that Bailyn’sJEHreview appeared) until summer 1953.53In Paris, Lane provided important funding for the Ecole, worked with Clemens Heller to develop “area studies” in the Cold War reconstruction of European academic institutions and intellectual life, and played an important role in introducing American‐style social sciences, especially a modern kind of economics that emphasized theory, statistics, and history and was intended to supersede the traditional business law discipline of the French university.54

ThisJEH“conspiracy” theory thickens with the addition of Earl J. Hamilton (1899–1989), who was president of the Economic History Association (theJEH’s parent organization) in 1951–52 and was long connected with the Harvard CREH.55In addition to having his invisible hand on theJEHeditorial board, Hamilton was a professor of economic history at the University of Chicago and editor (1948–54) of Chicago’s prestigiousJournal of Political Economy.Hamilton, who is mentioned frequently in the Braudel biographical materials, is remembered fondly as a great friend from the Spanish archives in Simancas starting in the summer of 1928.56One would have expected a review ofLa Méditerranéein Hamilton’s journal. The only mention is an October 1949 citation in “Books Received”; there is no review.57This omission is even more curious since Braudel’s coauthored book with Ruggiero Romano on Livorno shipping was reviewed in Hamilton’s journal in June 1952.58Was Hamilton being polite to save his old friend the embarrassment of a bad review or snubbing him for a book Hamilton’s entrepreneurial history orientation did not approve?59With only sixteen citations of Braudel in theJournal of Political Economy(and two of those were in book notices, two in tables of contents, and two as part of paid advertisements for other publications), one could safely say that France’s leading economic historian of the postwar era, whose main interest in that discipline was in the power of markets, was not only a persona non grata but even a persona incognita to the market‐mantra driven Chicago School of Economics.60

In sum, economic, diplomatic, and Renaissance historians—all from Braudel’s closest subdisciplines—rejectedLa Méditerranéeon disciplinary and intellectual grounds and delayed Braudel’s U.S. reception. First among the detractors were the leaders of economic history at Chicago, Hopkins, Columbia, and Harvard, who opposed Braudel’s French‐style economic history.61Braudel’s own generation of economic historians among the Americans—Hamilton (b. 1899), Lane (b. 1900), and Cochran (b. 1902)—were the ones who blackballed his book and promoted Bailyn’s early negative reception of it. Similarly, the diplomatic historian Garrett Mattingly (1900–1962), whoseAHRreview had praised Braudel’s “originality and boldness,” still expressed strong reservations aboutLa Méditerranée’s repetitiveness, its selective use of evidence, and its many banal generalizations. Mattingly was “compelled to admit that the third section … [on] war and diplomacy … is disappointing … not merely because the account seems relatively perfunctory, and written without much enthusiasm, but chiefly because” it did not connect with what went before. Mattingly later would tell Columbia graduate students in Renaissance history of his strong opposition to Braudel.62And, incredibly, the U.S. Renaissance studies establishment let Braudel’s book pass in silence. Although his 1949 volume did not seem to garner much attention in U.S. scholarly journals early on, in autumn 1950 the New York bookseller Gregory Lounz took out a half‐page advertisement inRenaissance Newsannouncing the availability ofLa Méditerranée. 63Neither that journal (1948–66) nor its successor,Renaissance Quarterly(1967–98), however, reviewed either of the French editions or the English translation of Braudel’s book.64Finally, intellectual historians in the Harvard historiographical tradition generally mirrored the rejection of Braudel. H. Stuart Hughes, for example, denigrated Braudel’s book since it “marked a further step away from clarity of thought and presentation … was sprawling and invertebrate … lack[ing] a discernible focus.”65

What happened toLa Méditerranéeamong English and American readers in the next twenty years from 1951 to 1972 to make it a “classic” that was no longer disapproved? Lawrence Stone (1919–99) described the postwar English mood of “boundless optimism … [on the part of] us young men who returned from war in 1945”: “We were dedicated converts to theAnnalesschool of history based in Paris, and we were certain that the most intractable problems of history would soon fall to the assaults of quantitative social and economic investigation.… We waited breathlessly for each new issue ofAnnalesor theEconomic History Review,every one of which seemed to contain an article which opened up great new vistas of historical exploration and interpretation.”66Demand from a number of English publishers in the early 1960s led Braudel to attempt what some of his friends and colleagues considered sacrilegious, if not impossible—to revise the already‐classic 1949 first edition.67Likewise, a new American generation—for example, William McNeill (b. 1917), Robert Forster (b. 1926), and Orest Ranum (b. 1933), with the Harvard cohort of Bailyn (b. 1922) and Hughes (b. 1916) serving as the exceptions proving the rule—heard Braudel’s literary evocation of a vast geographic world, the synthetic claims of global history, and the use of social scientific methodologies as ushering in a new kind of history.68Braudel’s April 1968 seminar in Chicago and his spring 1976 lectures at Hopkins solidified his newfound audience in American academia.69Trevor‐Roper (b. 1914) identified such delayed acceptance as in the nature of a classic: “A classic, by definition, breaks through the accepted standards of its time, by which it must at first be judged. It may take a generation before it is absorbed and can be examined critically.”70What exactly did this younger generation of English and U.S. historians—not necessarily economic, diplomatic, nor intellectual history specialists—find in Braudel?

Trevor‐Roper (n. 11 above), p. 472.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Readers’ Responses
sec.p: First‐time readers of Braudel’sMediterranean,in fact, are invariably dazzled or daunted by his dizzying array of detail. Two British encomia reproduced for publicity on the jacket of the Harper & Row edition are exemplary.71Arnold Toynbee commends Braudel’s all‐encompassing vision: “His research, reflection, and judgment are magisterial and illuminating … on all points that he takes up—and there are no gaps in his survey; it is admirably many‐sided and comprehensive.” Trevor‐Roper praises the encyclopedic coverage: “We are amazed by Braudel’s range of illustration, his eye for detail, his power to select, animate, generalize. He seems to know every crease in these mountains, every island in that sea, every climatic freak, every human response to the problems which they pose.”

Mme. Braudel writes, as “a witness to the intellectual origins of Fernand Braudel,” that in 1939 “what he had in his head was a fantastic phantasmagoria of colors, of landscapes, of men, of great events and small anecdotes, a composite of what he recombined and resuscitated from life.” Readers have to see beyond the trees to the forest, just as Braudel the author had to rely on his prodigious memory to create an ensemble of the distant sea from his prison camp in Lübeck “from a thousand facts and a thousand details often very far removed from one another in time and space.” Mme. Braudel describes Braudel’s “intellectual adventure” as “a slow accumulation little by little not of ideas, and less even of a system of ideas, but of images by the millions, the fabulous spectacles of history, mixing yesterday and today. In all of it, not a concern for logic.” She identifies Braudel’s key organizing principle as “a spectacle—it is a spectacle that he says took off, not a previous idea”72and she quotes hisJMHautobiographical essay: “And my vision of history took on its definitive form without my being entirely aware of it, partly as a direct intellectual response to a spectacle—the Mediterranean—which no traditional historical account seemed to me capable of encompassing, and partly as a direct existential response to the tragic times I was passing through.”73Turning that “spectacle” into a “vision of history” is a first, shorthand answer to our question of what readers remember.

Second, readers of Braudel’sMediterranean,no matter how much of the book they actually have read, continue to be struck by the energy, engagement, and dedication of a fervent lover and committed convert. “I have passionately loved the Mediterranean, no doubt because I am a northerner like so many others in whose footsteps I have followed.”74This famous opening sentence in the preface to the first edition, dated May 1946, one year after VE Day and Braudel’s release from a German prisoner‐of‐war camp, resonates in Braudel’s remarks during a 1981 interview thirty‐five years later on his initial excitement at seeing the Mediterranean for the first time in October 1923 at the age of twenty‐one:
It was for me such a surprise! I did not know the sea, I saw the Mediterranean, avowing that it is a present of the gods! Imagine someone like me who went down the Rhone Valley for the first time, who stopped at Marseille, who embarked on a boat and learned with pleasure that he had sea legs—it was just like that—and abruptly saw the arrival of Algiers on the horizon.… Algiers was the most beautiful city in France, after Paris, and a city itself very different, with, I would say, the beauty of its streets, the extraordinary beauty of its women.… It was hot, there was wine, fish, everything that one wants. For me, I began to live.75
North Africa freed Braudel, like so many earlier enchanted and enthralled romantic travelers, from his provincial complaisance. One can almost hear him chanting Goethe’s 1787 credo on finding one’s true self in the liberating southern sun: “I hardly recognize myself. I feel like a completely different person. Yesterday I thought: ‘Either you used to be mad, or you are now.’”76Or we see him “venturing out [into the desert] on a camel”77like Gide’simmoralisteMichel, the fictional professor at the Collège de France, discovering a new culture and self in 1902, the year of Braudel’s birth, at the Roman amphitheatre in El Djem. Such enthusiasm, excitement, and experience Braudel wishes to share with his readers; and the 1949 preface continues with the hope that the pages of his book would shine forth with “a little bit of this [personal] joy and a great deal of its [Mediterranean] light.”78

Memory and reciprocity between author and reader, in the way a good teacher connects with students, is also part of Braudel’s earliest writing ofLa Méditerranée; this is a third approach to the question of readers’ responses. In the preface to the first edition Braudel invites the reader to participate in the book’s image‐ and memory‐making: “The reader who approaches this book in the spirit I would wish will do well to bring with him his own memories, his own vision of the Mediterranean to add colour to the text and to help me conjure up this vast presence, as I have done my best to do.” And in this same spirit of memory and reciprocity, Braudel in turn returns to his own student days to remember the “unwavering conviction” imparted by his teachers: “if I have retained nothing else from the geographers who taught me at the Sorbonne,” it was that the “sea itself, the one we see and love, is the greatest document of its past existence.”79Thus it is not by chance that Braudel’s 1969 manuscript on the Mediterranean in prehistory and antiquity (“la très longue durée”), not published until 1998, is calledMemory and the Mediterranean,and its opening paragraph, with the heading “Seeing the Sea,” eloquently explains how memory reconstitutes reality for Braudel: “This is a sea that patiently recreates for us scenes from the past, breathing new life into them, locating them under a sky and in a landscape that we can see with our own eyes, a landscape and sky like those of long ago. A moment’s concentration or daydreaming, and that past comes back to life.”80The Braudelian metaphor is resuscitation and re‐creation. There is not the slightest hint of spiritualist resurrection; Braudel invokes instead the dynamism of waves. “Mediterranean civilization spreads far beyond its shores in great waves that are balanced by continual returns. What leaves the sea comes back and then departs once more.”81And even though these waves can turn into metaphors of precision instruments—“waves of past time which ought ideally to accumulate like the divisions in the mechanism of a watch, the seconds, minutes, hours, and days”; or, again, the waves of long to short‐term time through the three parts of his book itself, which are likened to “an hourglass, eternally reversible”82—Braudel is only a scientist in that he describes more than he explains. Better, he presents himself as the artist painting images, the novelist telling a story, or the playwright staging a scene.

Mme. Braudel, again our best witness, confirms that the Braudelian itinerary never followed the path “of a logician or a philosopher. Perhaps that of an artist?” She even recalls a telling conversation in which Braudel laughingly agreed that his “method” (“c’est un peu ce que je fais”) was a little like that of “Matisse redesign[ing] every day the same portrait of the same model … and each day regularly throw[ing] his design away in the wastebasket, until the moment that he finally had found the line that pleased him.”83Earlier in her testimony she emphasized a similar point. Braudel carried in his head all his experiences—sights, smells, tastes—without the need “to explain them to himself logically or methodically.” Rather, he was like a poet who enjoyed the moment; “but this poet was also, contradictorily, a professor” who had the uncanny facility of “perfect clarity” and “the memory of an elephant.”84

Braudel’s connection with his readers through spectacle, passion, and memory gives life to the numbing facts of his book. Although not of a philosophical or theoretical bent, Braudel began the 1967 introduction to the first volume ofCi vi lisation matérielle et capitalismewith a bow to theory: “A general history always requires an overall model, good or bad, against which events can be interpreted. ‘No theory, no history,’ said Werner Sombart.”85Braudel’s underlying “theory” or original organizational schema inLa Méditerranéegrew out of necessity and distance—the accumulation of masses of material over more than a decade and the enforced separation from his notes and documentary base while a POW. It was a theory grounded ingéographie humaine,the primary discipline supporting French historical instruction from elementary school, and forged in war.86It was more a practice than a theory; it was about war and remembrance, the incantation of memory, as he emphasized in his 1950 inaugural lecture to the Collège de France.87The revised 1966 edition, however, was reconstituted out of a critical rereading and rethinking; for Braudel’s method—the method of the originalAnnalesof Marc Bloch and Lucien Febvre—was the criticalcompte rendu,incorporating combats and debates, judgment and analysis in reviewing books and articles. In the 1969 preface to hisOn History,Braudel explained his method of revising his own work: “Since I am not a man of polemic, being concerned only with my own path, my own particular path, and since polemic and dialogue are a double and unavoidable necessity, here I am holding dialogues and engaging in polemic with myself, in a natural process of detachment from texts for which I obviously remain responsible. It was this sentiment which led me recently to rewriteThe Mediterranean.”88

Braudel’s 1966 revisedMediterraneanwas a different book. It changed its perspective from a focus on geography to a greater emphasis on economics, political science, a revised conception of civilization, and demography.89The second edition jettisoned outdated controversies and outmoded arguments, added new problematics and archival references, and synthesized the enormous body of new monographic work on socioeconomic history amassed in the previous fifteen years, often inspired by his first edition.

Reconstructing Braudel’s intellectual itinerary and mapping its congruence with twentieth‐century French social thought follows John Elliott’s 1973 observation that “in a sense, the history of Braudel’s great book is the history of twentieth‐century historiography itself.”90The revised second edition was the fruit of postwar optimism and of the “time of certainties” most associated with the success of Braudel’s first edition and his stewardship of theAnnalesand of the Ecole’s Sixth Section during the 1950s and 1960s. Even more fascinating, however, is the afterlife of Braudel’s 1966 edition ofThe Mediterraneanin the last third of the twentieth century, long after the text itself was set forever in typescript and translations. The problem of the disjunction between structure and event, the question of human freedom and individual action, the proof claims of language and quantification, the subordination of politics—all came under intense scrutiny and critical revision within France by subsequent generations ofAnnaleshistorians. Thus, the criticism of Braudel’sMéditerranéewithin his own tradition itself spawned new historiographical formulations and projects.

Beginning in the early 1960s, and punctuated by Foucault’s 1966Les mots et les choses(The Order of Things) and his 1969L’archéologie du savoir(The Archaeology of Knowledge and the Discourse on Language), poststructuralist critiques of truth claims and the imperialism of global history, a rethinking of the certainty of words and concepts in an “archeology (that is, a deconstruction) of the social sciences” struck at the heart of long‐standingAnnalisteprinciples.91Whether studying social control, discipline, power, or sexuality, old assumptions were dissected and new agendas initiated. The 1976Il formaggio e i vermi(The Cheese and the Worms) by Carlo Ginzburg and the 1979 launching ofmicrostoriaby Ginzburg, Carlo Poni, and Edoardo Grendi—practiced in France by Le Roy Ladurie in his 1975Montaillouand 1979Carnival in Romans—fostered a new kind of ethnographic history of everyday life that focused on the individual.92“The revival of narrative,” whether from Lawrence Stone’s famous 1979Past and Presentarticle or Paul Ricoeur’s 1983–85Time and Narrative,was to restore the story to history and to return to the event, as Pierre Nora had called for in his 1974 essay inFaire de l’histoire. 93Pierre Bourdieu’s 1979La distinctionpushed for a reconciliation between events and structure.94By emphasizing that systems of oppositions are not stable structures but are constantly in the process of becoming, being made and remade, Bourdieu’s project to understand how social reality is constructed gets us closer to incorporating practice and perception with objective categories and suggests a way of bridging the gap between the endless details of one thing after another and causal explanation. This list of keyAnnalisteideas and methods derived from theMéditerranée’s problematic could include sharp criticism like that of François Dosse; the constructive response of Jacques Revel on theAnnalesparadigms, the social sciences, and the construction of the social; Pierre Nora’s crystallization of the concepts of “the explosion of history” and “les lieux de mémoire”; and Bernard Lepetit’s response to the “critical turning point” of the late 1980s in the epistemology, research practices, and exchange among the social sciences with his 1995 collection of essays on “forms of experience” as “another social history.”95We might apply Braudel’s own metaphor of the sea to his book—that it was like a pebble dropped in the water, creating concentric rings of wider and wider ripples, both material and intangible.96That is why what follows—a discussion of the author‐historian’s life and influences—matters.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: The Man and His Book
sec.p: The long gestation period of the book—Braudel’s life to 1949 and beyond—forces remembrance of the man and his book. On the intellectual plane, as we have seen, Braudel’sLa Méditerranéeis a history of the Mediterranean and Philip II’s Spanish empire as well as a primary document illustrating the trajectory of twentieth‐century French historical studies and social thought both before and after its publication and revision.97On a biographical level, it was the sum of his personal experiences and studies, as Braudel’s preface to the first edition in 1949 recalls: “I have joyfully dedicated long years of study to it—much more than all my youth.”98Already in his forty‐seventh year at the time of the book’s publication, Braudel had had an eventful life; but it should be remembered that at mid‐century he had not yet made his mark nor won an established academic position in France, as, for example, his colleague Ernest Labrousse (1895–1988) or his American peers Hamilton and Lane had done long before.99Braudel himself knew what his friends thought about his never‐ending book: “among my friends and colleagues it was reported that I would never finish this very ambitious work.”100In 1976 he himself would correct the common false impression of the positive reception in 1947 of his thesis and theAnnalesmovement in general—“without drum and trumpet and with a thousand nice‐sounding words in my ear,” he was rejected for an appointment at the Sorbonne and received condescending criticism at his thesis defense. “One of the judges suavely said to me, ‘You are a geographer: let me be the historian.’”101Braudel saw himself as a perpetual outsider, an exile, not unlike the self‐image of theAnnalesitself, memorialized at the Binghamton inaugural conference, as a historical tradition of resistance.102Yet, in the administrative sphere, in his post‐1950 career as director of theAnnales,the Ecole, and the Maison, Braudel’s keen intelligence, force of personality, power with words, and moral authority from his war experiences made him a formidable presence in French intellectual and academic culture.103

Mme. Braudel summarizes “the very slow, independent, and solitary maturation” ofLa Méditerranéein terms of, on the one hand, “the isolation of prison,” and, on the other hand, “the isolation of university practices.” Braudel’s was “a very chaotic life, chopped into many bits and pieces of which each had been a sort of adventure and particular experience.”104She specifies Braudel’s successive experiences in rural France, North Africa, Brazil, and German prisoner‐of‐war camps. These four sites in Braudel’s biography and his autobiographical recollections about them are well documented.

Braudel was a self‐proclaimed, patriotic northerner, born in 1902 in the tiny Lorraine village of about two hundred inhabitants, Luméville‐en‐Ornois (Meuse). He spent his early years there until the age of seven with his paternal grandmother, Emilie Cornot, whom he calls in his dedication inThe Identity of France“lumière de mon enfance.” Thereafter, until the age of twenty‐one, he returned for summers and holidays from his parents and school in Paris, where his father was a secondary school teacher. Paris may have been where the young Braudel lived and went to school for fourteen years, where in later life he remembered his school chum Jean Gabin (1904–76), the great actor; but Luméville was his home, where he learned the nitty‐gritty of preindustrial material life, the names of plants and the rhythm of planting, became acquainted with the village artisans and the arts of village life. Upon completion of university at the Sorbonne in 1923, his ambition was to teachlycéelocally in his region and to become its historian. Mme. Braudel remembers how “a historian of the Meuse was amused to find all the allusions to the village of Luméville” inLa Méditerranée,as if it were a local history writ on a larger scale.105McNeill goes so far as to say that “Luméville undoubtedly provided the inspiration for thelongue durée… [and] provoked Braudel’s most successful innovation in the writing of history: his insistence on the basic importance of geographically variegated everyday custom and almost unconscious routines, which, he claimed, set limits to all deliberate effort, whether in matters economic, political, or military.” And McNeill believes that Braudel found an audience in the “French reading public” much because his work evoked that “vanishing world.”106

This idyllic youth between city and country was followed by academic exile and exclusion—eight academic years (1923–32) teachinglycéein Algeria, three years (1935–37) at the newly founded University of São Paulo in Brazil, and five years (1940–45) as a German prisoner of war at Mainz and Lübeck. As different as these experiences may appear, they all reinforced his self‐image of the exile, even when Braudel had ascended to the triple crown of priest, king, and prophet at theAnnales,the Ecole, and the Maison.

In 1923, when Braudel was appointed alycéeteacher of history in Algeria, he spent the first year working in Constantine; thereafter he taught in Algiers until 1932 (save for eighteen months of military service in the Rhineland, April 1925–October 1926).107He returned home to Luméville in the summer of 1924 only to receive news of his beloved paternal grandmother Cornot’s death. In Algeria, he seems to have enjoyed life as a bachelor bon vivant, given to discovering and enjoying North Africa and its colonial charms. “I thus had the opportunity to give myself over to the pleasures of living in a magnificent city with great joie de vivre, and to visit intensively all the countries of North Africa, into the Sahara, which fascinated me.… Some day perhaps apied noirsettler will write a book likeGone with the Windabout those lost years. At any rate, I did not personally feel any twinges of conscience. The bad conscience would be there twenty years later.”108What do we make of such extraordinary candor? Is the jarring reference to Scarlet O’Hara lingering romanticism, the French civilizing mission, or longing for lost innocence?109Braudel’s memories bear the curiosity of discovery, the seriousness of study, the naiveté of a twenty‐year‐old in the 1920s, and the sentimental nostalgia of the French colonialpied noir. 110

A psychological turning point in Braudel’s life came at age twenty‐five with his father’s death on January 27, 1927.111That summer Braudel returned to Paris to help sort out family affairs. He began his first serious archival research at the Archives Nationales and the Bibliotheque Nationale and changed the title of histhèseto “Philippe II et la politique espagnole en Méditerranée de 1559 à 1574” (i.e., from Cateau‐Cambrésis to the Turkish reconquest of Tunis). That fall his mother came to Algiers to keep house for him, which prompted him to undertake a first marriage with the daughter of the vice‐principal of his school on October 27, 1927, which ended in divorce five years later. Archival work in Simancas began in the following summers, 1928 through 1933.112His 1928 first article, “The Spaniards and North Africa,” was derived from his revisedthèsetopic, and it eventually made its way into Part III ofThe Mediterranean,in a discussion of the North African defense network. Neither this section nor a topic such as the battle of Alcázarquivir (August 4, 1578) constitute anything other than “potted” history derived from 1930s scholarship—nothing, in fact, to suggest his intimate contact with North African society and culture.113If the view of “the Mediterranean as seen from the opposite shore, upside down” revolutionized his vision, his geographic orientation tuned out any unique or original perspective in this section of what became Part III. In 1930 Braudel served as an assistant secretary at the Congress of Historical Sciences held in Algiers amid the celebrations of Algeria’s one‐hundredth anniversary as a French colony, and he appears to have been less on the outside than his memory or self‐image would like to admit. More than the place, it was what he did there, his role as a secondary school teacher, that shaped the young Braudel.

In July 1932 Braudel became engaged to one of his formerlycéestudents, Paule Pradel, from apied noirsettler family, then departed Algeria for a newlycéeassignment at Neuilly outside Paris, returning to France via Tunis and Italy, which he visited then for the first time. In September 1933, the thirty‐one‐year‐old Braudel returned to Algeria to marry the nineteen‐year‐old Paule Pradel in her hometown of Tiaret, between Oran and Algiers in the Algerian interior. The Braudels began to work together in Mediterranean archives in 1935 during their Brazilian winter vacations, and the “delight in discovering the marvelous registers of Ragusa at Dubrovnik” in 1936 was highlighted in Braudel’s memory. “For the first time, I saw the Mediterranean of the sixteenth century.”114

Just as North Africa provided a defining perspective that turned his thinking upside down, teaching in Brazil and captivity in German prisoner‐of‐war camps also gave Braudel important reflective distance. Brazil provided a different kind of colonial perspective to look across the ocean at the Mediterranean as through a distant mirror. For Braudel, Brazil’s stark class divisions resembled an earlier stage of European economic development and a way to look back in time at the origins of modern capitalism in the Mediterranean. “Brazil is the same civilization [as ours], but not at the same age. It is true that Brazil allowed me to arrive at a certain conception of history that I would not have had if I had remained round about the Mediterranean.”115Prison camp, in contrast, brought enforced solitude to contemplate the whole, away from the jumble of details in Braudel’s notes. Prison was a “long time of testing … a good school. It teaches patience, tolerance.” The Mediterranean “distracted me in the true etymological meaning of the word,” and Braudel wrote his book. “Only my memory permitted this tour de force. Had it not been for my imprisonment, I would surely have written quite a different book.… Far removed from our persons and our daily misery, history was being made, shifting slowly, as slowly as the ancient life of the Mediterranean, whose perdurability and majestic immobility has so often moved me. So it was that I consciously set forth in search of a historical language—the most profound I could grasp or invent—in order to present unchanging (or at least very slowly changing) conditions which stubbornly assert themselves over and over again.”116Braudel’s memory juxtaposed the repetition of the routines of daily life amid a sea of imperceptible change with the retelling of the same events during the reign of Philip II from different frames of reference in the three parts of his book, so that the temporal linkage between structure‐conjuncture‐event would become clear. Thus, the spatial separation between his life experiences in North Africa, Brazil, and the German camps would meld into a mnemonic device to understand and to teach how, in the lands around the ever‐changing and never‐changing sea, time and space, history and geography together shaped one coherent past, present, and future.

Teaching, above all, launched Braudel on his intellectual itinerary. It was first in North Africa where he encountered the “joy” and “spectacle” of life outside his circumscribed world of farm and family, school and books. In colonial Algeria, he began his adult life and his life’s work as a teacher trying to make sense out of the historical spectacle and its spectacular stories in order to formulate lessons for his students. The Socratic teacher never forgot his point of departure in North Africa.117

fn.p: Horden and Purcell, and Marino, are two recent examples.

Braudel,La Méditerranée,1st ed. (1949), p. ix: “Je lui aurai consacré avec joie de longues années d’études—pour moi bien plus que toute ma jeunesse.” On the length of time in composition, the English edition of 1972 quotes Nigel Dennis, “It took twenty years to write this remarkable book, and one cannot pay it a higher compliment than to say that twenty years could be well spent reading it” (vol. 1, back cover), and Geoffrey Parker, “No serious student of history can afford to be without a copy. It may have taken twenty‐six years to write, but which historian would not willingly sacrifice half his working life in order to create a masterpiece which will stand forever?” (vol. 2, back cover).

Braudel, “Foreword,” in Stoianovich (n. 14 above), pp. 15–16, and Daix (n. 2 above), pp. 343–44. Ibid., pp. 14–16, Braudel emphasizes his exclusion from the elite, degree‐granting French universities and from directing graduate student theses, and he calls the Sixième Section of the Ecole “the miracle, for its creation hung by a thread in 1947.” Despite his 1949 appointment to the Collège de France, his 1949–54 tenure as chair of the history section of the national examination (aggrégation), or his positions in the Sixth Section of the Ecole or in the Maison, Braudel saw himself and his group as “heretics until almost 1968,” when “the troubles of May and June 1968 changed everything.” He compares his own marginalization outside the prestigious degree‐granting universities offering graduate student instruction in France with the exclusion by the Collège de France of Marc Bloch and Henri Berr. See also Immanuel Wallerstein, “Annalesas Resistance,”Review1, nos. 3–4 (1978): 5–7.

Among the many testimonials upon Braudel’s death, Jacques Le Goff remembered him as “a ferocious partisan of the independence of spirit and of constructive disobedience,” and Georges Duby recalled, “I once wrote that he was the patron.… He had something of the prince in him,” as cited in Daix (n. 2 above), p. 539.

Ibid., p. 239.
McNeill, “Fernand Braudel, Historian” (n. 2 above), p. 135.

Braudel, “Personal Testimony,” p. 449, records his university and postuniversity malaise: “a student of history … graduat[ing] without difficulty, but also without much real enjoyment. I had the feeling I was frittering away my life, having chosen the easy way out.” Before he was to find his “vocation as a historian,” he “taught a superficial history of events, … becoming what one may call a good teacher,” liking and being liked in turn by his students.

Ibid., pp. 450–51: “I believe that this spectacle, the Mediterranean as seen from the opposite shore, upside down, had considerable impact on my vision of history. But the change in my viewpoint was slow. At any rate, at that point in my life I did not understand the social, political, and colonial drama which was, nevertheless, right before my eyes. It is true that it was not until after 1929 that the North African countryside grew darker, and then, suddenly, the night had fallen. I have my excuses. First of all, the need to live when one is twenty, paying attention to oneself alone—a good and a bad counsellor; the difficulty of learning Arabic (I tried seriously and did not succeed); my particular anxiety about Germany which I had just seen at close hand, a country which I loved but which, as a man of eastern France, I distrusted. And above all it must be said, in 1923, in 1926, and in the years which followed, French Algeria did not appear as a monster to my eyes.”

In the parallel English colonial tradition, we might think of a Lawrence Durrell character from the “Alexandria Quartet” (1957–60) or one of the sophisticated European archeologists in Anthony Minghella’s filmThe English Patient(1996), dining, drinking, and dancing to jazz at the country club. Braudel,The Mediterranean,2d ed., 2:1239, 1242–43, adds references to Durrell and other novelists—Carlo Levi alone is cited in the first edition (pp. 1091–92)—to emphasize “those local, permanent, unchanging and much repeated features which are the ‘constants’ of Mediterranean history.” Braudel even quotes Durrell, “Under the formal pageant of events which we have dignified by our interest, the land changes very little, and the structure of the basic self of man hardly at all.”

For a short, still useful introduction, see Charles‐Robert Ageron,Modern Algeria: A History from 1830 to the Present,trans. Michael Brett (London, 1991), pp. 82 and 86 on population statistics. In 1926, the European population was 18 percent of the native Muslim population, that is, 833,000 Europeans, which included 657,000 French and naturalized French and 176,000 foreigners, while the Muslim population stood at 5,150,000. In 1931, 76 percent of the European population was urban—673,000 out of 881,600.

Daix (n. 2 above), pp. 73–74 and elsewhere, provides suggestive indications for a psychoanalytic approach regarding Braudel’s deep attachment to his paternal grandmother, ambivalent love/fear of his father, and estrangement from his mother.

Braudel, “Personal Testimony,” p. 452, tells us that during these years, “I lived in the archives without hurrying—not even hurrying to choose my subject—that my decision ripened of its own accord. And so I chose the Mediterranean.”

Daix (n. 2 above), pp. 137–38, quotes Braudel’s memories of 1937, his last year in Brazil: “Le Brésil, c’est la mème civilisation, mais pas au mème âge. C’est vraiment le Brésil qui m’a permis d’arriver à une certaine conception de l’histoire que je n’aurais pas eue si j’étais resté autour de la Méditerranée.” Daix, pp. 109–23, provides a chapter on Brazil with the opening quotation, “C’est au Brésil que je suis devenu intelligent” (p. 109); he compares Braudel’s understanding of French colonial society in Algeria as placed on top of an indigenous society, whereas “the Brazilian social hierarchy [presented itself] less a local than an international economic” phenomenon (p. 111). See also the interview by François Ewald and Jean‐Jacques Brohier, “Un vie pour l’histoire,”Magazine littéraire212 (November 1984): 18: “Au Brésil, j’ai d’couvert ce que je ne connaissais pas, et avec une certaine violence: quelque chose qui ressemble à une haute société privilégiée d’autrefois, quelque chose, au bas de la société, qui ressemble au début de la vie industrielle française, etc. En tout cas, c’est au Brésil que je suis devenu ce que je suis aujourd’hui.”
Braudel, “Personal Testament,” pp. 453–54. See also Daix (n. 2 above), pp. 163–200.

Lydia Cochrane first told me this story in 1992/93, and reconfirmed it May 31, 2003 (personal communication). She remembers that in the Braudels’ desire to reciprocate the endless round of dinners offered them in April 1968 during their first month in Hyde Park, she accompanied Mme. Braudel around all of Chicago searching for a couscous pan that Mme. Braudel might use for a return dinner to repay the hospitality they had received. The Braudels’ North African dinner was scheduled for Saturday May 4, and this led Braudel to downplay the increasingly urgent telephone calls and news of May 1, 1968 coming from Paris. “What I remember with greatest pleasure,” Lydia Cochrane writes (personal correspondence, November 6, 2003), “is trying to sympathize with M. Braudel in his supposed anxiety and getting the answer. ‘J’en ai vu d’autres,’ with an Olympian shrug of the shoulders.” Finally convinced of the gravity of May 1968, the Braudels decided that as soon as their Hyde Park couscous dinner was completed, they would fly back to Paris and forgo the rest of the spring quarter.

sec.p: Albert Camus, who should have been that Algerian‐colonial writer, if not strictly apied noir,that Braudel curiously invoked in his 1972JMHreverie of an AlgerianGone with the Wind,was born in Oran in 1913 and beganlycéein 1923, the same year Braudel arrived to teachlycéein Constantine.118He attended the University of Algiers between 1932 and 1936, beginning his studies there just as Braudel was leaving Algeria for Paris and then Brazil. Camus published his great novel,The Plague,in 1947, the year of Braudel’sthèse;and Camus himself spent 1949, the year ofLa Méditerranée’s publication, in Brazil. These superficial correspondences have no causal relationship; rather, their juxtaposition evokes the mental world of denial and disjunction between France and Algeria that France maintained as the colonial power, the combatant in two world wars, the humiliated defeated dependent of Nazi Germany, and the postwar recovering power. InThe Plague,“Camus’s insistence on placing individual moral responsibility at the heart of all public choices”119presents a vision of history that appears to be diametrically opposed to that of Braudel’s “possibilism.”

Similarly, the haunting image of the schoolteacher Daru, who isl’hôte—the simultaneous “guest/host”—in Camus’s Algerian short story in his 1957 collectionL’exil et le royaume,contrasts sharply with what Braudel remembered as the innocence of colonial Algeria thirty years before.120After freeing the Arab prisoner to allow him to choose his own destiny, Daru returns alone to his classroom. One can see the colonial classroom, the maps and chalkboard tools of the teacher, the Algerian landscape of sky and plateau and “the invisible lands stretching all the way to the sea” focusing our gaze on what it really means to be alone and an exile. The last paragraph of Camus’s story is as biting for us today as it was for France in 1957, the year that Camus received the Nobel Prize in Literature121and that the French scored their Pyrrhic victory crushing terrorism in the “Battle of Algiers.”122“A little later, standing before the window of the classroom, the schoolmaster was watching the clear light bathing the whole surface of the plateau, but he hardly saw it. Behind him on the blackboard, among the winding French rivers, sprawled the clumsily chalked‐up words he had just read: ‘You handed over our brother. You will pay for this.’ Daru looked at the sky, the plateau, and, beyond, the invisible lands stretching all the way to the sea. In this last landscape he had loved so much, he was alone.”123Have the lessons of the schoolmaster in geography and politics been learned? Whose landscape and whose politics was or is it?

The actions of Camus’s schoolteacher were not circumscribed or constrained by geography: they were the political decisions made from an assent or acquiescence to “dogma, compliance, and cowardice.”124Because Braudel, always the schoolteacher, so emphasized his brief against biographical history, critics have often claimed that the delineation of limits and constraints inThe Mediterraneandevalues politics and events and leaves the book devoid of individual freedom.125Such misrepresentations distort the history that Braudel really presented: “The dangers of a social history are clear to us all, and in particular the danger of forgetting, in contemplation of the deep currents in the lives of men, each separate man grappling with his own life and his own destiny; the danger of forgetting, perhaps even of denying, the inimitable essence of each individual.”126For Braudel, the lessons of World War II demanded remembering both the forces acting upon each individual and individual acts freely chosen.127Braudel’sMéditerranéewas a call to arms: “The catastrophes and revolutions, dramas and surprises” of his time revealed “the social reality, the fundamental reality of man … in an entirely new light,” which in turn required a new history, a problem‐oriented and global, total history.128It was a new history slow to be understood, little to be appreciated, and rarely to be practiced in the Anglo‐American world remembering a different past and fighting different battles in the 1950s and 1960s. On the question of individual freedom, however, Braudel’s history of the sixteenth‐century Mediterranean is very similar to the work of its most brilliant contemporary political analyst, Machiavelli. We might recall the wily Florentine exile’s astute judgment when we reread the last words of Braudel’s penultimate paragraph in the second edition: “I would conclude with the paradox that the true man of action is he who can measure most nearly the constraints upon him, who chooses to remain within them and even to take advantage of the weight of the inevitable, exerting his own pressure in the same direction. All efforts against the prevailing tide of history—which is not always obvious—are doomed to failure.”129Braudel, the self‐proclaimed exile, would chronicle a plethora of facts no longer merely to entertain his students with “a superficial history of events” but in order to remember the contingency of choice and to teach how to discern the times. Thus, the Renaissance predicament offortunaandvirtù—what an individual can do in the face of what he cannot control—was also the twentieth‐century “paradox” studied and taught by Braudel: how to act within the parameters of the possible to fulfill both one’s own and mankind’s destiny.

fn.p: Camus, the younger of two children, whose father, a day laborer, was killed during World War I and whose mother, a Spaniard, was illiterate and deaf, grew up in extreme poverty and attendedlycéethrough a scholarship. On Braudel’s memories of Algeria, see above n. 108.
Tony Judt, “On ‘The Plague,’”New York Review of Books(November 29, 2001), p. 6, from his introduction to the new Penguin Books translation by Robin Buss (2001).

Albert Camus, “L’hôte,” inL’exil et le royaume(Paris, 1957). The plot explores the formal and personal divisions between two cultures as the French schoolteacher Daru (who lives deep in the desert interior) is brought an Arab prisoner (guilty of murder) and is ordered to deliver him to prison for execution.

Camus outlined his idea of his art and the role of the writer that is resonant with the title of his short story collection,Exile and the Kingdom,in his 1957 Nobel Prize acceptance speech, available online (http://www.nobel.se/literature/laureates/1957/camus‐acceptance.html): “[My art] is a means of stirring the greatest number of people by offering them a privileged picture of common joys and sufferings. It obliges the artist not to keep himself apart; it subjects him to the most humble and the most universal truth.… By definition he cannot put himself today in the service of those who make history; he is at the service of those who suffer it. Otherwise, he will be alone and deprived of his art. Not all the armies of tyranny with their millions of men will free him from his isolation, even and particularly if he falls into step with them. But the silence of an unknown prisoner, abandoned to humiliations at the other end of the world, is enough to draw the writer out of his exile, at least whenever, in the midst of the privileges of freedom, he manages not to forget that silence, and to transmit it in order to make it resound by means of his art.”

Ageron (n. 110 above), p. 115: “The ‘Battle of Algiers,’ lasting from January to September 1957, ended in the destruction of the terrorist organization in the capital [as a result of governor‐general Robert Lacoste giving ‘the paratroopers the task of destroying the terrorist commandos in the city “by any means”’], but psychologically it proved a pyrrhic victory” since it radicalized the Muslim population of Algeria and alienated public opinion in France. See also Benjamin Stora,Algeria, 1830–2000: A Short History,trans. Jane Marie Todd (Ithaca, N.Y., 2001), “The Cruel War (1957),” pp. 49–56.
Albert Camus, “The Guest,” inExile and the Kingdom,trans. Justin O’Brien (New York, 1967), p. 109.

Judt, p. 9, inThe Plague:“It was not ‘fascism’ that Camus was aiming at—an easy target, after all, especially in 1947—but dogma, compliance, and cowardice in all their intersecting public forms.” Camus aimed at a more universal problem, the problem of evil, and the moral dilemmas that evil presents to individuals.

Braudel addressed the critics directly inThe Mediterranean,2d ed. (1972), 2:1243–44: “The question is frequently put to me, both by historians and philosophers, if we view history from such a distance, what becomes of man, his role in history, his freedom of action?” A classic example is embodied in Braudel’s portrait of Philip II himself. “What degree of freedom was possessed by Philip II, or by Don Juan of Austria as he rode at anchor among his ships, allies, and troops? Each of these so‐called freedoms seems to me to resemble a tiny island, almost a prison.” See the conclusion of Part III, 2:1236 that recounts the death of Philip II on September 13, 1598, based on three secondary sources of the 1920s, not from contemporary accounts of Philip’s “good death.” Braudel’s last poignant paragraph suggests that Philip did not know what he was doing: “[Philip] was not a man of vision: he saw his task as an unending succession of small details. Every one of his annotations is a small precise point, whether an order, a remark, or the correction of a spelling mistake or geographical error. Never do we find general notions or grand strategies under his pen.” The king’s “grand strategy,” however, is exactly what Geoffrey Parker set out to demonstrate inThe Grand Strategy of Philip II(New Haven, Conn., 1998). Braudel may be correct that Philip, as a prince, was not a student of geography. But what Philip did study, architecture, emphasized design. No discipline was more useful to understanding “general notions or grand strategies.” Thus, Braudel’s Part III, as traditional as it is often said to be, appears to get the story and the king wrong because Braudel’s steering assumption, not Philip II, was in control: “Good reasons for us to reflect once more on the distance separating biographical history from the history of structures, and even more from the history of geographical areas” (2:1237). For a similar critique, see also M. J. Rodríguez‐Salgado, “Dust and Ashes: The History of Politics and War,” inEarly Modern History and the Social Sciences(n. 2 above), pp. 145–67, esp. 164–65, which argues for greater focus on Philip II and his empire as in herThe Changing Face of Empire: Charles V, Philip II and Habsburg Authority, 1551–1559(Cambridge, 1988). Already in McNeill’s 1972JMHintroductory note, he hinted at the problem: “M. Braudel, who in writing of himself and his intellectual forerunners offers a remarkable example of both the strengths and weaknesses of theAnnalesschool—perspicacious, penetrating, and detached, even in analyzing himself; yet, though in principle disdainful of mere occurrences, unable to explain his own history except in terms of personal encounters, friendships, conversations, yes and rivalries!”

Braudel, “The Situation of History in 1950” (n. 73 above), p. 20, continues, “For to challenge the enormous role that has sometimes been assigned to certain outstanding men in the genesis of history is by no means to deny the stature of the individual as individual and the fascination that there is for one man in poring over the fate of another.”

Hexter (n. 11 above), pp. 509–10, argues that Braudel’s experiences in German prison camps created his vision of the importance of thelongue duréeover the short term as “a necessary act of faith, the narrow path to salvation” and survival. His point is reinforced by Daix (n. 2 above), p. 452.
Braudel, “The Situation of History in 1950” (n. 73 above), pp. 6–8. See also Hexter (n. 11 above), pp. 510–12.

Braudel,The Mediterranean,2d ed. (1972), 2:1243–44. Among many references to Machiavelli, see, e.g., Machiavelli,The Prince,chap. xxv, beginning of last paragraph: “I conclude, then, that so long as Fortune varies and men stand still, they will prosper while they suit the times, and fail when they do not.”
